🤯 this is excellent!

For anyone wanting to test this out, here is a quick guide for enabling Docker on YARN:
https://community.hortonworks.com/articles/226331/dockerized-yarn-services-quickstart.html

It was tested with HDP 3.0.1 from Hortonworks. Available here:
https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/index.html

The steps are similar with a base Apache Hadoop installation (version 3.1.1 or higher).

The DB poll is periodic and there is a race between getting the results from the poller vs active ack. Until the poll is cancelled (which is scheduled by the active ack), it remains active. Further, the future which continues with its callback could be executed in any order. Because of how close the log statements appear in time, I don't think the effect is necessarily what you might be hinting at: that the result message is ignored for completing the blocking request --- which you can assert with a test otherwise.

the reason why I found this is that we have a custom feature which can skip saving activations into DB when some request parameters are set, then some of these requests will hang until timeout and return a 202 response
Should we use this opportunity to set the default min to 64MB?

@csantanapr Reducing the general limit from 128 MB to 64 MB would potentially mean a higher number of concurrent actions per invoker when keeping the same amount of action memory on the invoker. As a consequence the CPU consumption may double. Increasing the potential CPU consumption on the one hand may also require CPU capping for action on the other hand.

At the moment, the Docker container implementation does not support CPU capping. We should definitely look into this topic.

I had the impression we were already calculating the cpu share by using the fraction of the memory limit proportion since we currently pass the “--cpu-shares” flag. 

So I don't follow, less memory would mean more actions, higher density per invoker, each action with small men gets smaller cpu share.

CPU shares just makes sure that a cgroup receives a minimum amount of CPU if and only if all CPUs are 100% loaded. It has no influence on the maximum CPU share a single cgroup receives.

See https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/cgroup-v1/cgroups.txt and https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/scheduler/sched-bwc.txt.

I guess the problem lies somewhere in the details of physical / virtual memory, container (cgroup) rss / swap memory limits and overall system memory.

The exception stack starting with `RangeError: Array buffer allocation failed` says that the Node.js could not allocate the requested amount of _virtual_ memory. See https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/v6.15.0/lib/buffer.js for the underlying Node.js version 6 code.

To explain why this error happens, let's run the `free -hw` command on the global system and within a memory limited standard action container (256 MB):

```
# free -hw
              total        used        free      shared     buffers       cache   available
Mem:            15G        2.3G        1.5G        101M        832M         11G         12G

# docker exec -it 05b670eafb46 free -hw
              total        used        free      shared     buffers       cache   available
Mem:            15G        2.6G        1.5G        101M        832M         10G         12G
```

There is barely no difference between the global system and the container. Let's ignore the small differences in output for now. Even though there is a memory limit defined on the container, it seems to have 15G RAM. Containers (i.e. namespaces) do not influence the results of memory management kernel calls because there is no memory namespace [1]. The container "thinks" it has lots of memory even if there is a limit on the physical memory.

If you request an amount of (virtual) memory - regardless of whether you are in a container or not -, you will receive a positive result if the kernel thinks it will be able to contain the requested memory. It won't reserve any physical memory pages for your request. [2]

When receiving a `RangeError: Array buffer allocation failed`, the kernel returned a failure because the overall system (or VM) must have been short on memory. So the kernel decided that it cannot contain a contiguous block of 256 MiB of virtual memory.

As already mentioned, when you receive the desired amount of virtual memory, it's simply table entries but not backed by physical memory.

If you start filling the memory, the memory management system will receive page faults whenever you touch a virtual memory page for the first time and provide a physical page backing the virtual page. This is where the action container limits apply: The memory subsystem has an accounting how much physical memory is owned by the container. Once the actual physical memory reaches the defined limit, the memory subsystem tries to reduce physical memory pressure of the container (cgroup). The final action is to invoke the out-of-memory (OOM) killer which stops the process with the highest score. The process consuming most physical memory usually has the highest score.

BTW: if your action code starts a child process which consumes more physical memory than your main process, the OOM killer will stop the child process. At the same time, the main action process holding the communication socket to the invoker will continue to run normally. You won't see an OOM error of the action.

Another interesting detail: some operating systems and VMs perform memory de-deplication [3]. If you allocate a large buffer and fill all virtual memory pages with the same values, it may end up with a single physical page representing all required virtual memory pages. That's why our current action [4] may fail to provoke the desired OOM kill in some environments.

Based on these details, I suggest to follow this strategy:
* Set the action's memory limit to the lowest possible value. At the moment, we set it to `128.megabytes` which is actually the limit. We should use `MemoryLimit.minMemory`.
* The action should allocate exactly the limit. I guess this should already be sufficient.
* The action should determine the system's page size and fill one randomly chosen byte on each page of the buffer with a random value. On the one hand, that's probably faster than writing each byte. On the other hand, this prevents memory deduplication or compression.

Nevertheless, if the system has too few memory, this strategy won't help either.

[1] http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man7/namespaces.7.html
[2] https://linux.die.net/man/3/malloc
[3] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kernel_same-page_merging
[4] https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/tests/dat/actions/memoryWithGC.js

@chetanmeh I'm sorry to bother you. 
I have found the reason that  virtual memory of my vps is running short the kernel OOM (Out of Memory) killer forcibly kill individual builds, you can check the original answer [here](https://stackoverflow.com/a/39705290/8119453). 

I increased `swap` space and then build success.

```
cd /opt
mkdir swap
cd swap
dd if=/dev/zero of=swapfile bs=1M count=10240
mkswap swapfile
swapon swapfile
```

It looks like there's a configuration error in your ansible/db_local.ini file because the second script is connecting to http://192.168.222.140:5984 instead of 172.

This is what the `ansible/db_local.ini` file should look like:
```
> cat ansible/db_local.ini
[db_creds]
db_provider=CouchDB
db_username=whisk_admin
db_password=some_passw0rd
db_protocol=http
db_host=172.17.0.1
db_port=5984

[controller]
db_username=whisk_local_controller0
db_password=some_controller_passw0rd

[invoker]
db_username=whisk_local_invoker0
db_password=some_invoker_passw0rd
```
